And ere not we as Waſpiſh and impatient now, at every idle word, as the Gilieadites, (by Iudg. 12.4 Ephramites) to be called runnagates: as DAVID was at the Curriſhneſſe of 1. Sā. 25.22 NABAL; and ABISHAI, at the revilings of 2. Sā. 16.9 SEMEI: doe we not take the leaſt diſgrace (as our Tobaccho) in ſnuffe? Are our Academickes more patient to be put by theyr Graces, at our publike Commencements, than thoſe of China? Who if they be excluded and thruſt out as Cyphers, in cheir exquiſice Math. Riccius expeditione ad Sinas, l. 3. c. 9.
Tryals, uſually run mad and diſtracted: are our Divines more patient to be put by a Benefice by any Senior immerito, Act. 8.19. that hath gifts like SIMON MAGVS, rather than SIMON PETER, more than AERIVS (and ſome ſay NESTORIVS and PAVLVS Apud Magdeburgenſes, et Oſiandrū, in Epit. Cent. SAMOSATENVS) who are ſayd to turne Heretiques, (as ſome of ours Campian. Creſewell. Rainolds. Carter. Papiſts) becauſe they miſt of that praeferment, which they gaped for? Are our Courtiers more patient of Corivals, than HAMAN of a E • th. 5.13 MORDOCHEVS: the Princes of DARIVS of a Dan. 6.3.4 DANIEL: are we more patient of Baniſhment, than ABSOLON from the Court of 2. Sā. 13.3 Iſrael, amongſt the Geſhurites? Or OVID amongſt the Getes, Ovid de Triſtibus. and Sanromatians, are we not as impatient of Impriſonment, and the reſtraint of Liberty, even the meaneſt of
us, as was Quomodo Huniades, bis captus, et his evaſit lege Chronica Melancth. lib. 5. p. 64. et 650. & deincarceratione Mathiae patris. apud Camer. 2. oper. Succ. c. 3. p. 190.
Huniades, Valerian the Emperour, BAIAZET the Turke: RICHARD the ſecond: ROBERT Duke of Normandy: ROGER Byſhop of Salisbury (whom we have formerly named) with other ſuch great De omnibus hiſce incarceralis (quibus addi poſſunt) ex Germaenicis, Henricus 4. ex Gallis, Carolus Martellus: ex Turcis, Amurathej. ex Perſis Jſmael 2. ex Graecis Dioniſ. ex Gal. regibus Chilpericus. ex Hiſpanis, Filia vinco Regis Caſtaliae Maſi • iſſa ex Numidis, ex Mediolanenſibus Ludovicus Sfortia ex Aug. Comes, Richmontius cum multis alijs. ſpirits? Are we more patient of diſreſpect any way, though our meanes be but meane, what ever our inſide bee? Then men of excellenter knowledge, and morall parts, than wee in former times? Could we without grudging, feed on Pulſe with Dan. 1.12. DANIEL and his three Companions? Could we goe clad in Camels haire? (As in rug'd Mantles) and feed on Locuſts, as IOHN the Mar. 1.6. Baptiſt? Could wee beg a peece of Barley bread with ELIAS? Bee driven to ſeeke our lodgings we know not where, with the Levite Iudg. 19.15. and his Concubine? Could wee lye hard in the Fields and in Tents as 2. Sam. 12. VRIAS? Could we weare old ſhooes, and eate mouldy bread with the Ioſh. 9.12.13. Gibeonites? And cut Wood as they, and as PHILOPAEMEN once the Plutarc. in vita eius. Orator? Draw water as CLEANTHES in the Night time? Serve a Baker and be ſtint of our bread we eate, as once Apud Serv. & Sabel. VIRGIL? Yea, beg our bread, as ſome ſay HOMER Herodit. in vita eius, & Scalig. in Poeticis. did? I am ſure as great Date obilum Bolliſario. BELLISARIVS, and that Cynicke DIOGENES did: and the Capuchians 1. Kin. 17.10. Theat. Phil. l. 4. p. 340.
now doe? Could we be contented to be excluded, and not admitted to a Feaſt, as was the caſe once of that famous Gomeſius l. 3. c. 31. de ſale. Dantes, the Italian Poet, becauſe of our meane cloathes (which neyther Gnatho nor Thraſo reſpects?) or if admitted, to be ſet, as Terence once at the lower end of Cicilius his In Vita Terentij. Table, beneath the ſalt: (uſually the Chapleines place?) Would we not take it as unkindly, as that Phyloſopher in In Lapith. convivio. Lucian, if we were not invited? And as harſhly as that ſpruce Gentleman in Apud Plut. Praetextatus, or as the Luk. 14.7 Scribes in the Goſpell, if we did not perke up to the higheſt place? It might bee, wee would ſhrinke away chafing and repining, as too much neglected. Could we be content to have our ſecrets diſcloſed, or our infirmities publikely revealed, to our diſgrace: more than that Gentlewoman which Ronſeus tells Epiſt. Miſcel. 3. us, grew mad or melancholly, upon ſuch an occaſion? Can we be patient, to play the Courtiers, or to Act the parts of wiſe Pilgrims, and ſtrangers, to receive iniuries and give thankes? Can we heare our ſelves reviled (as Pyrrhus once by certain Drunkards: as Charles the 5. by his muttering Cavete dixit audit Imperator, apud Iovium Souldiers: yea as Socrates when hee was brought upon the Stage by Ariſtophanes) and yet diſſemble all and take no notice: paſſe by as a Lyon, or Courſer thorow barking Curs, nor caſting downe head, nor lifting up heele: but (as that Albanian Dog, preſented to Geſuer de quadr • pedibus, tranſlated by Topſell. cap de Cambus. Alexander: vindicating and revenging our ſelves meerely by Contempt: as holding it a moſt Princely thing: yea, that which is incident to GOD himſelfe: to doe well, and heare Regium eſt bene facere, et male audere. evill, of a blaſphemous multitude:
or rather doe we not as Bees, Waſpes, and Hornets, ſting upon the leaſt ſtirring, as Curs barke and ſnarle at every pibble ſtone that is flung▪ beſides, are we patient at the loſſe of our goods, as was the Patriarke Iob. 1. Vltimo. IOD; or as theſe Pagans Olim nobilis attamen pauper Florus lib. 4.
Thales and Bias? Can we be contented with Poverty, as were not onely the Pagans, the Curij Fabritij? But even the 2. King. 4. Prophets, the Acts. 3.6. 2. Cor. 6.10 Apoſtles, yea CHRIST Foxes haye holes. himſelfe: as GVALTER well notes, and gives the Lucam c. 2. v. 18.
Reaſon: Doe wee approve of all theſe Encomiums given of it; by Scriptures, Pro. 11.4 Eccleſ. 4.13 Fathers, Aug. Cōf. l. 6.
Philoſophers, Qu • t Clari docti, & virtuto praeſtantes viri punperimi fuere, vide apud Aelian. l. 5. lib. 9. l. 11. Pontanum, de Fortit. l. poſter. p. 76. & apud Patritium, l. 9. de regno, tit. 10. pag. 595
Orators, Hor. Sat. 6. l. 2. Serm. Poets, or rather doe we not fly it, as a mad Dog, Beare, Tyger, or Snake, as MOSES from his Rod, turn'd a Serpent? If we get not, and gaine not, at every commodity, or mercenary ware we deale with, if we make not mony contrary to Nature; and GODS Inſtitution, to increaſe, and D. Fentous book againſt Vſury. multiply: but chiefly, if we goe downe the Wind, and looſe ought, we then thinke we are utterly undone: we rage, and rave, as MICHAYES Iudg. 17.2. Mother, when her ſonne ſtole her ſilver: yea ſome have run even ſtarke mad, as Birds fit to be Caged in Bedlam, as did that ROGER the rich Byſhop of Salisbury, being ſpoyled of all his Goods and Mannours by King Stephen, Vi doloris obſertus, even ſwallowed of ſorrow, he did and ſaid, he knew not what: ſaith NVBRIGENSIS: at leaſt we grow melancholy and male-content, as Montanus Conſil. 26.
Phyſitians tell us of ſome in ſuch caſes: yea ſome as leaping out of the Frying-pan into the
fire, out of diffidence, diſtruſt, carnality, Athiſme, Infidelity: looſing their ſilver, even looſe their Soules too, by being Felons and Butchers, upon themſelves, like TERENCE the Comedian, that would needs drowne himſelfe, becauſe ſome of his Comedies periſht by Shipwracke, not conſidering that many great men, Noble men, Good men, yea learned men, have beene poore, yet reſpected for their guifts and Ariſtotle by the great Macedoniā, apud Ca • ier. tent. 2. Virgil, Horae • , and others, by Auguſtus Pollio and Mecaenas Eunius, by Scipio, Diogenes and Calamus by Alexander: Eraſmuus by Sir Thō. Moore. So Cardan, Geſher. Lipſius, by other Patrons.
graces, whereas wicked men that have beene wealthy, have beene rejected, and diſreſpected, for their retchleſſneſſe, notwithſtanding their riches.

Beſides, who can ſay that he is abſolutely contented with his eſtate? That ſayth, his Lot is falne on a faire ground: that's indifferent whether hee be higher or lower, or in a meane and indifferencie, as the wiſe Pro. 30 8. HAGAR wiſht? That is willing to ſhape his Coate according to his cloath: to beare ſaile, juſt as he hath Winde and Water, that with the 2. Kin. 4.15 Shunnamite, dwelt amongſt his owne people: without much troubling, or being troubled by intermedling: that lives and reignes, as a Vice-roy and Centurion over his Affections: that is indifferent whether hee bee carried in a great Boat or a little, ſince hee reach and attaine, his ſcope and Haven: but rather, how few ſuch, are there amongſt us? How rare are ſuch Blacke Swaus, as the Poet thought in his Rara avis in torris, Nigro ſimilim • Cygno. time? How are our heads ſtill working, as new Wine in the Veſſell? And how ſtill conſulting and projecting by our ſelves and Friends: (as HAMAN with his
Wife Eſth. 5.10 11 ZERESH, and Counſellers: ABSOLON with 2. Sā. 16.20 ACHITOPHEL; AMON with 2. Sam. 13 3.4 IONADAB, PIRRHVS with his Orator Patrit. l. 2 de regno tit. 3. pag. 92. CYNEAS: ALEXANDER with his EPHESTION, DARIVS with his ZOPIRVS, AGAMEMNON with his Axiom. polit Richteri Gorlicij axiom. 45. pag. 124. NESTOR and VLISSES) ſtill, how to bee more great, rather than how to bee more good.

13. So how can we bridle theſe Concupiſcible appetites, in reſpect of all Luſts whatſoever? Are we ſo mortified from deſire of Honour, which we call Ambition: from that Philangury or love of money which is called Covetouſneſſe, from that Philantia and deſire of Vaine-glory and applauſe, that we flye it as a Tanquam mater multorum malorū, authore Daneo, l. 3. Eth. p. 310.318. ſic Strigellio, in 2. Sā. 12. p. 138.
Crocodile? Or from effeminacy and love of Women: or from exceſſive and inordinate love of other Earthly things, as were the Apoſtles, and Primitive Martyrs and Confeſſors, that forſooke all to follow CHRIST: or as PAMBO, ANTHONY, HILARION, MACARIVS, PAVLVS SIMPLEX, and other Heb. 11.36.37. Hermites, and Anchorites: that pretended,Of the ſtrict lives of theſe and many moe, read Sozomen, l. 1. c. 12 and it's probably intended, to place their Affections onely on things above, and not on things below: yea, are we ſo moderate and mortified (in the outward man, at leaſt) as the very Heathens? Love we money? No better than Fabritius, that refuſed the guifts of the Apud Tul. Samnites, Honors? No better than Phocian the Athenian, who fled from Nudis pedibus ple • um
que incedebat, apud Plutarc. Magiſtracy? (As that Martin in the Eccleſiaſticall Hiſtories, Apud Soc. lib. 4. c. 30.
Ambroſe, and others, from being Byſhops:) Women? No better thā Anaxagoras who was no more mooved with the allurements
of Lai • , than a ſtocke or a ſtone? Yea are we ſo indifferent for all other externals, that we could content our ſelves like that Cynicke, with our See Staff. Diogenes: Anglice. Tub, and a Booke, and a Diſh? Or as that Iſraelitiſh Prophet, with a Chamber, a Stoole, a Bed, and a 2. Kī. 4.10 Candleſticke? Or with that Diocleſian (after he was elected Emperour) with a Imperium ſponte depeſuit, Lelius Zecchius l. 1 de principe, c. 4. & Philippus lib. 3. Chron. Cottage-houſe: like an Iriſh Cabbin, and a little Garden, with a few herbes, roots, and Lentiles for food, with apparell as meane? As did the Iewiſh De quibus Joſephus de bello Jud. l. • cap. 7. & antiq. l. 18. c. 2
Eſſein: the Indian
Ʋnus exiſtis Brackmannis fuit Calanus Indus vt Cicero habet in l. 1. de divin. & 2. Tuſcul. quaeſt. Brachmians, and Herod. l. 5. c. 5. & The. hiſt. l. 7. cap. 48. pag. 814
Gymnoſophiſts: the Popiſh De quo ſtricto ordine, Hoſpinianus, de Orig. Monoc. l. 6. c. 67. p. 297
Capuehians now: Alexanders Calanus: or Staffords Diogenes: when by Sycophantizing, and obſervance, he might have beene a Favorite to Alexander, and beene in Grace as Calco Platonis Faſtum. Plato, and Si ſciret regibus vti, faſtidiret Olus. Apud Hor. Ariſt. de Diogene. Ariſtippus: theſe Courtly Philoſophers? I doubt we come farre ſhort of theſe, and ſuch as theſe? If we would ingenuouſly confeſſe (what other zealous and devout ſpirits have confeſſed before us, in their Sololoquies and Meditations) keeping a true audit, in our hearts, and a Court in our Conſciences, we ſhould againſt our ſelves give in In ſoliloq. Auguſtines Verdict: that our hearts are even rent, and raekt, and torne in peeces, with Multiplicities of deſires, now haling one way, now another, as two Birds, that are flackering, and flying at the two ends of a threed, one drawing Eaſtward, the other Weſtward, we would confeſſe with Jn Ca • ticis. Bernard,
the reſtleſneſſe of our deſires, to be thus and thus (as a long • ng Wife, deſiring now this now that) in ſuch diverſifyed paſsions, that we can no more reckon, and number than the Sands of the Seas, or Motes in the Sunne: our appetite extending it ſelfe to every thing, that ſuperfluouſly we ſeeke after: our deſires being reſtleſſe, as a man that runs in a round, or traceth in a laborinth: or as a Horſe, that goes about in the Milne, as though our thoughts and cogitations every minute, did roule Siſiphus his Rela • entem Saxum, ad Montis verti • em, perpetuo volvens apud inferos Ovid • . Metam. ſtone: or turne Ixions Rotam perpetuam voluere fingunt quod ſe Juncne gloriaretur concubuiſſe. Tibullus l. 1. & Seneca in Hercule Furente. Wheele: or, as if we were layd on a Bed, on which it raines, turning now this way, now that: or ſtretcht on a Racke, ever in paine, and perplexity, till we be taken off. For Ambition? We would confeſſe we had beene, and are infected with this Canker, this Oh Ambitio ambientū Crux. De variis cenſuris doctorum vide ſupra, Margine. plague, this poyſon, as the learned call it: that we had beene hunted with this Hag: and pricked forward; (like a Bird or Squirrell in a Cage: an Ape in a chaine: a Dog in a turne-ſpit Wheele) ſtill to climbe and climbe, though we never come to the top: in danger ſtill to fall, as the Goat that ſeekes after Ivie, upon old Trees and rotten wals. For Covetuouſneſſe? We would confeſſe, that even this weed too, had grown and ſpread as a Pompion, and ſeeded too farre, in the Garden of our hearts, & that (according to the counſell of Hypoc to Grateva the Herbaliſt) we had not yet ſo rooted it out: but the remainders have beene left: as the cauſe (if we beleeve Jn varijs ſermonibus, et homilij • , ad populum Antioch. Chryſoſtome) of the moſt of the miſeries and maladies of our life. And for popular applauſe? Who is it amongſt many, but with that
Themiſtocles thinks it the beſt Muſicke? Who but is ſometime tickled with it, as that Grecian Orator: that tooke delight to heare even the vulgar Hic eſt ille, Demoſthen. Athenians, to whiſper and point with their fingers, This is Demoſthenes, as he paſt by them: Auguſtine himſelfe when he was a Manichee, and a Rhetorique Lecturer at Millaine, as himſelfe Jn l. Confeſ. At pulchrū eſt digito monſtrari, et dicier hic eſt Perſ. Satyr confeſſeth, being (Tyger-like) too much affected with theſe clawings and ticklings. By which that proud Herod was as a man, tickled even to death: whē the Angell plagued him, as his Sydonians palpably praiſed him. So for Effeminacy? How few can we adde in our owne experience to that Catalogue of Chaſtones, Chriſtians and Pagans, Virgins and Widdowes, which that Contra Jevinianum. Chaſt-Father enumerates in his Antagoniſticall oppoſition againſt Iovinian? As they are alledged by that once zealous Chancellor of Genſon. Paris: nay, if we durſt reveale our harts & thoughts to any, but the knower and ſearcher of hearts, we would confeſſe with the ſame Hierom, in one of his Epiſtles: that when our bodies were cooled and beat downe with Quoties ego, in eremo conſtitutus. Jeinnijs mens aeſtuabat deſiderijs. paines, and Faſtings: our ſoules and affections, were burning and boyling in concupiſcentiall deſires.

14. So for the Iraſcible Faculty? Who amongſt a thouſand, was ever ſeene like Socrates, Zeno, and other Stoicks, for the moſt part, ever in one temper? (As Seneca Lib. de Ira. reports of Cato) who was ever ſeene free from paſsions? Or indeed: (becauſe no man can attaine to that perfection, which the Stoicks dreame of, to bee continually freed from all paſſions and perturbations whatſoever,
ever, no more than the Sea from waves, the Ayre from windes: ſince as the Learned note, wee propagate them from our Parents, and bring them with us into the world, and to put them off, and to bee inſenſible of evils, (like that ſtupid Nation of Africke, which Aubanus ſpeakes of) were Exuere hominem, to put off the nature of a Man, and to bee (as is ſayd of a Solitary man) eyther a GOD: an Angell, or a Beast: an Eagle, or an Owle: a Saint, or a Stocke) who keepes this Paſſion of Anger, like the Sea, within his bankes and Et exemp. & preceptis Antidota & Pharmaca contra hanc Jram. habemus apud Senecam, lib. 3. de Jra. Zene. lib. 2. Cyrop. Oroſ. l. 2. cap 16.
limits: who can ſo farre bridle and moderate thoſe fierce Bellerophon horſes of Angry heates by that minerva of Reaſon; that hee can ſay of his offending inferiour, as once Plato to his Servant; I would beate thee if I were not Angry? Who can ſo farre maſter and conquer this Paſsion, as (following the counſell which Athenodorus give to Auguſtus,) hee can repeate over the letters of the Greeke See Maſter Downam his Treatiſe of Anger.
Alphabet, ere hee execute any Mulct and penalty in his anger? But rather as bruit Beaſts, incenſed Tygers, and inraged Vnicornes, inflamed and wholly fiered with this Paſſion; carryed as with a tempeſt or whirle-wind, as beſides our ſelves, as hee acknowledged in the Apud Plaut. Comedian: in a ſhort fury Ira furor brevis eſt: animum rege Hor. l. 1. Ep. or frenzy, with ſparkling Et ex oculis Micat. acrius ardor: Lucr. l. 3. de rer. Natur. ſcintillant oculi, dicis faciſ
que quod ipſe, non ſani eſſe hominis: non ſanus Juret Oreſtes, Perſ. Sat. 3.
eyes, ſtammering Ora tum. Ira. Ovid. l. 3 de Arte amandi. Tongues, gnaſhing Morde • t. labia Jracandū deſcribit Homer. Odyſ: 1. in procris Jratis, in Telemach. Teeth, grinning like Lumina Gorgoneo, Savins angue Micant, Lucr. Dogs, foaming like Jracunda
que mens, viceſt vi
• lenta Leon. Boares, (as this Atae is ſet out) wee play oft ſuch mad prankes, as did that haire-brained Aiax in Homer: that
Medea Actu. in Euripides; that lunaticke Charles the ſixt, in the French hiſtorie; that Alexander in Quintus Curtius: when he ſtabd his deare Apud Plutarc. & Strigell. in Ethic. lib. 1. p. 247
Clitus, and cut off his valiant Apud & Curtium, et Bodinum, lib 4. de Repub. c. 7. p. 736.
Philotas; as Soliman in the Turkiſh hiſtory, when hee ſtrangled the martiall Muſtapha; yea, as Apud eundem, pag. 74 1. Et apud Patritium, l. 6. de rep. tit. 5. pag. 289.
Pauſanias, that paſſionately murthered King Philip; or inraged Herod, that leap'd out of his Bed and killed Ioſippus; as that cholericke Contaren the Venetian, who (rejected in an Office) ſtabd the Duke of De iſto Cō tareno Codro et Herode: vide, Democritum Juniorem, de Melanc • lia. Venice; as Anthony Vry (called the Learned Codrus) that for the loſſe of his burnt Library, dyed madde; and as that carnall Cardinall Hypolitus, who full of furie in an angry Frenzie, puls out the Eyes of his Brother Count Guic • ard. in his hiſtory of Italy. Iulio, as his Corrivall in his Loue or lust; or as that Ninacheturin the noble Governour of Malacha, who being Commanded by Alphonſe, the Lieutenant of the Portugall King of the Petr. Hiſpal. et Maffa • s, de rebus Jndicis. Eaſt-Indies, to reſigne his Office, immediatly makes a fire and burnes himſelfe.

15. So who is ſo free from Envy and Emulation, at his Colleagues, Copartners, or Corrivals, (chiefly, if they in place, paines, parts, or praiſe paralell or exceed him) but hee findes an inward grudging? If not gnawing, about his heart? As the Moath (ſayth Cyprian,) gnawes the Garment; or as the Eagle in the Poet, is fained to gnaw the heart of Prometheus: and the Worme the Gourd of Ionas, 4. Ionas: yea, we cannot ſee our Inferiors advanced, but we labor of that Diſeaſe, wch Lypſius found in himſelf; we cannot looke upon thē, our ſelves being neglected, Sine gemitu & fremitu, without grieving
and grudging, every man would be ant Caeſar, aut nullus: eyther Caeſar, or no body: eyther a Knight; or a Knitter of caps: as the practice of proud ſpirits, verifies the Proverbe.

Concluſio totius.Thus in this Peroration, at laſt to draw to a Concluſion: we ſee the Tumultuations, roulings, revolvings, and reſtleſſe reekes, of our inordinate affections miſplaced, or too vehemently fixed upon wrong Obiects. Now let Clodius, Aegiſtus himſelfe, or the looſeſt Libertine & licentious wretch in the world bee judge, that hath any feeling or knowledge of theſe paſſages, ſpeculative, or experimentall in himſelfe, or others: if the Soule of man (which is the point I ſtill ayme at) can have any true contentation: aſſured Conſolation, or ſolid ſatisfaction: (which is ſtill as the concluſive underſong to the diſcanting of my larger Ditty) in theſe toſſings, tumblings, bluſterings, bickerings, bandyings, and exorbitances of the unruly paſſions? Is there any reſt in theſe, more than a man can ſleepe quietly in a ſurging Tempeſtuous Sea? Or on a Galloping Horſe? Onely when the affections are rightly tuned, and (as the right Gauntlet put on the right hand, the right ſaddle (as they ſay) put on the right Horſe: the right Lines met in the right Center) truly and duly placed upon God, mans ſole and ſoveraigne good: there they reſt; when the Love is ſo placed on God, as the ſoules ſpirituall Bridegroome, that all falſe and Adulterous Loves are abhorred and abandoned. 2. The filiall feare, ſo feares GOD onely, that Men, Divels, Tyrants, the Creatures, are not
feared: as by Faith curbed, by dependancy from a ſuperiour Power. 3.The full difference betwixt a Carnall ſorrow and a Chriſtian, a naturall and ſpirituall, ſee in Dike his deceitfulneſſe of mans heart: and Negus, of Mans active obedience, in 4. When the ſorrow is turn'd from a naturall, or adventitiall melancholy, from a Carnall, deadly, deſperate ſorrow, ſuch as is in Mat. 26.57 Worldlings, Hypocrites and Reprobates, into a godly ſorrow, (ſuch as was in Pſal. 6.6. David, Mat. 26.57 Peter, Luk. 7.44 Mary) meerely for ſinne; becauſe it is ſinne, and not as in Gen. 3.13 Cain, Exo 9.27 Pharaoh, Mat. 27 34 Iudas, Carnall Deu. 1.45. Iſrael, Heb. 12.16 Eſau meerely for the puniſhment of ſinne 4. When our Ioy is not as the Sodomites, and ſenſuall Wordlings, in Luk. 17.27 28. Eating, drinking, marrrying, and ſuch good bleſsings abuſed: nor in Luſts in their owne Nature ſinfull: ſuch as Chambering and Rom. 13 13, 14 Wantonneſſe, Surfetting and Drunkenneſſe, and all Sabyritiſh, Epicuriſh Voluptuouſneſſe: in which prophane ſpirits wallow (as the Eele in the mud, the Scarabean Flea in the Dunghill; the Swine in the Mire) but it is placed as was Davids; and the Priſtine and Primitive Saints; in the Pſal. 32.1 •
Lord: in his Chriſt, in the Ioyes of the ſpirit: in the Word, in the Pſ. 119 72 Law, in the Promiſes, in Gods Ordinances, and in the Saints, which Pſal. 16.3 excell. 5. When our Iealouſie is turned (as was Iobs and Davids) to our ſelves, and our owne wayes, that we offend not. 6. Our Anger turn'd againſt our owne ſinnes: into a holy revenge: and to a zeale of Gods glory, ſuch as was in Ex. 32.19 29.32 Moſes, Nū. 25.7.11 Phinees, 1. Kī. 19.10. Elias, Acts, 2.14. Peter, Act. 13.10. Paul, 2. Sam. 6.20. David, and our Pſal. 69.9. & Ioh. 2.17. Saviour himſelfe. 7. When as a Clock all the ſtrings of our affections, thus ſet, ſtrike right: then and not before, as the crying Child
that ſucks his owne deſired Dug? Wee receive from the Lord, the bleſſed Influence of plenary Conſolation, all ſufficient Contentation.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Theſe outward things uſed out of Chriſt in Carnalities, in the abuſe of Christian liberty: ever leave a ſting in the Conſcience more or leſſe: which deprives of all true Peace, and Contentation.
div.p:
LAſtly, my laſt Meditation runs briefly in this: that all theſe externals, be what they will bee, (not needing to particularize them againe in their ſeverals) even the choice, and chiefe of them; nay all of them, diſioyned, and diſioynted from the feare and ſervice of the true God: uſed and abuſed (as the faſhion ever is) by Wordlings, Naturaliſts, and meere Civill honeſt men, (which neyther know nor regard, that ſanctified vſe of the Creature, to the honor and glory of the Creator, which is taught onely, by the Word: in the Schoole of Grace, and not by the practice of the
world, or the precepts of morality, in the Schoole of Nature) all of them I ſay, thus injoyed, or ioyedin: or rather, meerely uſurped by vaine men, like Felons and Traytors incroaching on Gods beſt bleſſings, or purloyning to their owne abuſive ends, his beſt Creatures; cannot but leave a ſting in the Soule, and a pricke in the Conſciences of their deareſt Favorites: vnleſſe they be wholly 1. Tim. 4.2 ſeared, cautherized, and hardened, as the nether Millſtone, as was once Exod. c. 7. ch. 8, 9, per totum.
Pharaohs, and ſtarke dulled and dead, as that 1. Sam. 25 Nabal: no more penetrable, than the Adamant, or ſcales of a Dragon: For we muſt know, that the Conſcience doth not onely gall, and cut, and ſting, in the perpetration of great and notorious ſinnes, which (though they be tranſcient in Act) leave behind them a ſtaine, a blot, a ſpot, and a permanent Racke: ſuch as Cain, Nero, Caligula, Maximinus, Maxentius, Antiochus, Epiphanes, Herod, Pilate, Iudas, and many others, felt as their greateſt torment (this Guilt haunting them in their very ſleepes and dreames; chiefly, when the hand of God was upon ſome of them, in the extremities of their diſeaſes, in the houre of death: in the times of Lightning, Thunder, and other manifeſtations of Gods power, preſence, Iuſtice; as themſelves have acknowledged, as appeares by the Marginall De horrore terrore vindicto, et Judicio malae Conſcientiae in his et aliis inſtant et Antiqui & Moderni, inter alios. Ambr. l. 5. Epiſt. 18.
Authors: the guilt of Conſcience ever following and dodging ſinne, as the hew and cry doth the Felon, and overtaking it, as the Storme and Tempeſt the Fugitive Ionas:) but Iaverre further, that the Wicked have no Peace of Conſcience, even in the uſe of theſe things, that in
their owne Natures, are the good guifts of GOD, even poſitive bleſſings. Gold, Silver, Riches, Revenewes, Houſes, Lands, Farmes, Friends: H • alth, Strength, Honours, Dignities, Wife, Children, what ever they call and account good, are not good to them: or for them: no more than Wine is good for him that hath a Burning Feaver, Eeles and ſtirring meates for him that hath an Iriſh Ague: or much drinke for him, that hath a Method of Phyſick, l. 3. c. 2. p. 156 Dropſie; nay no more, than a Knife is good for a child, a Sword in the hand of a B • dlam or Mad-man, with which he wounds himſelfe or ſome other: their very Table (that's all their externall Proſperity) is a very ſnare to them, as the Pſalmiſt ſpeakes, it's as the Limb • -buſh to the Bird, the Trap which the great Nimrodian Hunter the Divell, ſets for their Soules, and as they have no good by them: ſo (which is the point I drive at) they have no true and ſolid Comfort in them: there's no peace to the Wicked, ſaith my Eſa, 57.21 On which Text read Adams Sermon. God: no kinde of true Peace in any thing that they ſet their hands too, and their hearts on; their Hearts, and their conſciences being Tit. 1.15. defiled the very in • als and • wards of their ſoules, beeing polluted; how can the cleare ſtreames, the ſweet fruites of Peace, proceed from ſuch a heart, ſuch • roo • , ſuch a fountaine, as is unpurged, and unpurified, by Grace? Since Grace, and Peace are alwayes (as that Eneas and Achates) Grace and Peace as Husband & Wife ſeeme married together, Rō. 1. v. 7. 1. Cor. 1.3. 2. Cor. 1.2. inſeparable, and individuall Companions, true Relatives as the two Cherubins looking one directly towards the other, one anſwering the other, as face anſwers face in a Glaſſe: as the Apoſtle ſpeakes of
Love, it holds too of Ioy, the other Siſter, both proceeding from the ſame Progenitors, a pure 1. Tim. 1.5 heart, and a good Conſcience: and as in ſome Births, the Mother and the Daughter, both live; or both As in the Caeſarian Section, Inſtā ces are givē by Geu •
out of Rouſſet and Banhin, & other Phyſitians, Hiſt. p. 259 ad 267. dye: ſo it holds in this; their hearts, are dead in reſpect of any Grace, therefore this roote, being dead, there can be no fruit; nay, no bad, no bloſſome, of any ſound and ſolid peace: they have theſe outward things indeed, oft times, in great abundance, even to the grudging and repining ſometime of GODS Children, (as appeares in the querulous Complaints of Pſal. 73. v. 1.2.3.4. & v. 21.22. David,
• ob. 1. per to • um.
Iob;
• er. 12.1.2 Ieremy, who as the Elder Brother, in the Lu. 15.29 Parable, ſeem to be neglected, in reſpect of theſe prophainer Prodigals, as though they had not an aequall portion; of that their Father were partiall in ſharing: allowing the rich purpled Ch • rle, dainty Lu 16.19 cates, whē Lazarus had not Verſ. 21. crums Iezabels falſe Prophets 1. Kin. 11.19 feaſting, when good Elias was kept faſting: the I • o • s Philiſtins being Ioviall and tryumphant all in their Puffe, and Iollity, ſwelling with pompe and 1. Kin. 17.11.13 pride, when Sampſon the Nazarite, was mourning and grinding in the Iudges. 16 23.24 Varſ. 21. Milne, NABAL feasting as a King, and in 1. Sam. 25.36. ſuperfluities, when good DAVID and his people, were Verſ. 8. diſtreſſed, for want of neceſſaries: yet nevertheleſſe; GODS Children have more Comfort, and Contentation in a Sallet of hearbes, in a little 2. Kin. 4.2 Oyle in a Cruce, and a cake of 1. Kin. vt ſupra.
Meale: than theſe pampred, luſt fed Stallions of the world,Ier. 5.8. in their ſtalled Oxen, more peace in peaſe & pulſe, with Daniel
and his 3. Dan. 1.12. Companions: than the other, the increaſe of their Wine and Pſal. 4.7 Oyle: becauſe they have them as dutious Children their Portions, though never ſo poore, with their Fathers bleſsing; as obſequious Servants they receive theſe gratuities, as tokens and Pledges of their Maſters Favour: as Rebeccha received Gē. 24.22 Iewels, as Teſtimonials of Iſaacks lo • e, whereas the other have their abuſed bleſſings, from God (as Sampſon had Dalilah, and the Tymnites Daughter from the Iudg. 14.4 Philiſtines, meerely to inſnare them; as the Troians had the Palladian Horſe, from the Greekes, to intrap them: God gives them theſe things in wrath: as he did give 1. Sam. 8.11.12. Saul, to the diſcontented Iewes: as that Iupiter in the Fable, gave to the croaking Apud Aeſopum. Frogs: a deſtroying Storke, for a King: having the Creatures without the Creator, they have no more comfort in them, than a vaine Man the miſpent Dowry of that Woman, whom he neyther loves, nor ever was beloved of her, his Matrimony being meerely aymed a matter of money, which God never joyned, nor ever bleſſed. Now the premiſſes conſidered, theſe outward things ſequeſtrated from the aſſurance of Gods love (being accompanyed (in all unſanctified hearts) eyther with too-working and waking a conſcience:) as in Saul, whom every thing troubled, friends, foes, Philiſtines, David, Ionathan, Michol, the Prieſts of Nob; yea the Evill Spirit it ſelfe, injoying no peace, though he were a valiant and victorious King; Or elſe with too Lethargicall, cautherized, and drowſie conſcience: as in Naball, who lived like a Belly-God, and dyed like a
Beaſt, which is no Peace, but a perilous ſecurity, the Herald and Prologue of their approaching deſtruction. In eyther of theſe, what true contentation hath the Soule? More than a Traytor in his Racke,
Securitaetis Comes ruina, Mel • eth. Tom. 2. pag. 431.
Penc. de Divinatione p. 67
a Felon in his Iaylor his Executioner? More than the Eye in the Moate or Pearle that paines it? The heele in the thorne that prickes it? The Toe in the corne that peſters it? Or the foot that is pinched in the Shoe-makers Stockes? This Vanity is vexation of Spirit.

div.head: CHAP. XX. The Peroration or Concluſion of this Tract.
div.p:
THus in theſe diſcuſſions, diſcourſes, diſcoveries, and demonſtrations, frō premiſſes truly grounded, both from Phyloſophy, and Theology: The principles of Art, Grace, and Nature, we have etrxacted our Concluſion at firſt propounded; as truely Orthodoxe (though to the bleare-ey'd world, it may ſeeme a Paradoxe) that as in the darker Night we have all the glimmering light of the Starres, yet we want the Sunne, which is Inſtar omnium, in ſteed of all: yea more than all, to the illumination of the World, to the chearing and refreſhing of Men and Beaſts: ſo in the darke Night of our Ignorance and Vanity, we may participate
of all the gliſtering and glimmering comfort and contentation which is in the Creature, and yet as children of Darkneſſe, romaine ſtill diſconſolate;Vbi Cimmerij extitere, eſt de Pr •
verbio Tenebrae Cimmeriae. Pli • . l. 3 c. 8. et 6. c. 6 Melancth. lib. 1. c. 4. as in Egyptian and Cimmerian darkneſſe, and in the ſhadow of Death, wanting the vivification, inlightning and inliving, which is from that Sonne of Righteouſneſſe, that Father of lights, that GOD of all Comfort and conſolation unto his Elect ones, the Children of Light.

And therefore (to knit up all in one word) as its the onely fiſhing in the Sea, with Peter, Iames, and Ioha, eſpecially when CHRIST is preſent: and the onely drinking at the Fountaine, rather then at dry puddles, ſtanding waters, marriſh bogs, or broken pits: So (ſince Pacem te poſcimus omnes) All would have true Ioy, peace and contentation, its the beſt courſe, and moſt compendious way to ſeeke it where it is to bee had, in the fountaine in the well-ſpring, and Originall of it, in GOD the one, and onely Author, donor, and giver of this true Comfort. Seeke not the living among the Dead, as the Angell revealed concerning CHRIST; ſo I ſay concerning that Conſolation which is ſought for of every true Chriſtian. Reſurrexit non eſt hic, its Riſen (yea and aſcended too) it is not here. It is an Eagle mounted up above, (as that vltima Coeleſtum, quae terras Aſtraea reliquit) Its returned to Heaven from whence it ever came, it is not to bee found heere below, in theſe things terreſtriall, they are too low, unworthy, the affections, love and deſires of that heavenly infuſed Soule which came from above.

Finally, in this caſe, the counſell of the Apoſtle is worthy our obſervation, worthy our imitation. Set your affections (therefore) on things that are above, and not on things beneath. Col. 3.2. Mortifie your earthly Members; whether Concupiſcible,Verſe, 5. as Fornication, vncleanneſſe, inordinate affection, evill Concupiſcenſe, and Covetouſneſſe, which is Idolatry; Verſe, 8. Or Iraſcible, as Wrath, Anger, Malice, Blaſphemy, and the like;Verſ For which things ſake (not onely) the wrath of God commeth on the children of Diſobedience, whereby they are lyable to an unſupportable curſe, but alſo, they doe euen ſo much diſappoint, diſorder, and diſtreſſe the Soule that is with them infeſted; that they utterly deprave it, deprive it, and make it uncapable of any true Peace, comfort and content.

I might heere amplifie at large upon theſe Vſes of Exhortation and Dehortation, and vſe divers Motives to both of them, to make theſe Conſiderations ſinke deeper into the drowſie conceipts of our bewitched Worldlings, and alſo to ſpurre forward, the ſlow motions of other tardy Chriſtians: But (by theſe that warily peruſe the Workes) enough may bee found (diſperſed in the Body thereof) to theſe and the like purpoſes.

Beſides, the Volume is ſwolne farre • ger in the Preſſe, then I ſuſpected by the Manuſcript, I will therefore drive this Part no further. The Apoſtles practice to the Hebrews ſhall be my patterne. I beſeech you Brethren ſuffer the words of Exhortation, Heb. 13. • 2 Galat. 6.18 for they are but few. The Grace of our Lord IESVS CHRIST, be with your Spirit, AMEN.
LONDON. Printed by B. ALSOP and T. FAVVCET, M.DC.XXXI.
